pairs.stoic_text:
Avoid public and vulgar entertainments; but if ever an occasion calls you
to them, keep your attention upon the stretch, that you may not
imperceptibly slide into vulgarity. For be assured that if a person be
ever so pure himself, yet, if his companion be corrupted, he who
converses with him will be corrupted likewise.
pairs.neutral_text: Stay away from crude or lowbrow entertainment. If you must attend such events, pay careful attention to your behavior so you don't accidentally pick up bad habits. Remember that even if you have good character, spending time with people who have poor character will negatively influence you too.

pairs.stoic_text:
If you have an earnest desire toward philosophy, prepare yourself from
the very first to have the multitude laugh and sneer, and say, “He is
returned to us a philosopher all at once”; and, “Whence this supercilious
look?” Now, for your part, do not have a supercilious look indeed, but
keep steadily to those things which appear best to you, as one appointed
by God to this particular station. For remember that, if you are
persistent, those very persons who at first ridiculed will afterwards
admire you. But if you are conquered by them, you will incur a double
ridicule.
pairs.neutral_text: If you seriously want to study philosophy, be ready for people to mock you from the beginning. They will laugh and make fun of you, saying things like "Look, he suddenly thinks he's a philosopher" and "Why is he acting so superior?" Don't actually act superior, but stick to what you believe is right, like someone who has been given this specific job. Remember that if you don't give up, the same people who made fun of you at first will respect you later. But if you let them defeat you, they will mock you twice as much.

pairs.stoic_text:
Never say of anything, “I have lost it,” but, “I have restored it.” Has
your child died? It is restored. Has your wife died? She is restored. Has
your estate been taken away? That likewise is restored. “But it was a bad
man who took it.” What is it to you by whose hands he who gave it has
demanded it again? While he permits you to possess it, hold it as
something not your own, as do travelers at an inn.
pairs.neutral_text: Don't say "I have lost something." Instead, say "I have given it back." Did your child die? You gave them back. Did your wife die? You gave her back. Was your property taken away? You gave that back too. "But a bad person took it from me." Why does it matter who was involved when the original giver wanted it returned? While you're allowed to have these things, treat them as if they don't belong to you, the same way travelers treat their temporary rooms at a hotel.

pairs.stoic_text:
You can be unconquerable if you enter into no combat in which it is not
in your own power to conquer. When, therefore, you see anyone eminent in
honors or power, or in high esteem on any other account, take heed not to
be bewildered by appearances and to pronounce him happy; for if the
essence of good consists in things within our own power, there will be no
room for envy or emulation. But, for your part, do not desire to be a
general, or a senator, or a consul, but to be free; and the only way to
this is a disregard of things which lie not within our own power.
pairs.neutral_text: You cannot be defeated if you only fight battles you can win. When you see someone who has high status, power, or respect, don't be fooled by appearances and assume they are happy. If what truly matters comes from things you can control, then there's no reason to be jealous or try to compete with them. Instead of wanting to become a general, senator, or consul, focus on being free. The only way to achieve this freedom is to stop caring about things you cannot control.

pairs.stoic_text:
Thus the _Enchiridion_ was liberating for all intellectuals who learned
from it that there are philosophical ways of self-redemption. From its
time, the secular thinker could feel jubilant because he was not in need
of a divine grace. Epictetus had taught him that philosophical reason
could make him free and that he was capable of redeeming himself by sound
reasoning.
pairs.neutral_text: The _Enchiridion_ gave intellectuals a sense of freedom because it showed them that philosophy could provide methods for improving themselves. After reading it, non-religious thinkers felt encouraged because they realized they didn't need help from God. Epictetus had shown them that logical thinking could give them freedom and that they could solve their own problems through careful reasoning.

pairs.stoic_text:
Men are disturbed not by things, but by the views which they take of
things. Thus death is nothing terrible, else it would have appeared so to
Socrates. But the terror consists in our notion of death, that it is
terrible. When, therefore, we are hindered or disturbed, or grieved, let
us never impute it to others, but to ourselves—that is, to our own views.
It is the action of an uninstructed person to reproach others for his own
misfortunes; of one entering upon instruction, to reproach himself; and
one perfectly instructed, to reproach neither others nor himself.
pairs.neutral_text:
People get upset by their opinions about events, not by the events themselves. For example, death isn't actually scary - if it were, Socrates would have been afraid of it. The fear comes from believing that death is scary. When we feel blocked, upset, or sad, we shouldn't blame other people. Instead, we should recognize that our own thoughts and beliefs are causing these feelings.

Uneducated people blame others when bad things happen to them. People who are learning blame themselves. People who are fully educated don't blame anyone.

pairs.stoic_text:
When any person does ill by you, or speaks ill of you, remember that he
acts or speaks from an impression that it is right for him to do so. Now
it is not possible that he should follow what appears right to you, but
only what appears so to himself. Therefore, if he judges from false
appearances, he is the person hurt, since he, too, is the person
deceived. For if anyone takes a true proposition to be false, the
proposition is not hurt, but only the man is deceived. Setting out, then,
from these principles, you will meekly bear with a person who reviles
you, for you will say upon every occasion, “It seemed so to him.”
pairs.neutral_text: When someone treats you badly or insults you, remember that they believe their actions are justified. They can't follow what you think is right - they can only follow what they think is right. If their judgment is based on wrong information, they are the ones being harmed because they are mistaken. When someone believes a true statement is false, the statement itself isn't damaged - only the person is wrong. If you understand this, you will be patient with people who criticize you, because you'll remind yourself, "That's what they believed was correct."

pairs.stoic_text:
The body is to everyone the proper measure of its possessions, as the
foot is of the shoe. If, therefore, you stop at this, you will keep the
measure; but if you move beyond it, you must necessarily be carried
forward, as down a precipice; as in the case of a shoe, if you go beyond
its fitness to the foot, it comes first to be gilded, then purple, and
then studded with jewels. For to that which once exceeds the fit measure
there is no bound.
pairs.neutral_text: Your body's needs should determine what you own, just like your foot size determines what shoe fits you. If you stick to this principle, you'll have the right amount of possessions. But if you go beyond what you actually need, you'll keep wanting more and more without any stopping point, like falling off a cliff. This is similar to how shoes work - once you stop caring about whether they fit your feet properly, you might want gold shoes, then purple ones, then shoes covered in jewels. Once you ignore the practical limit, there's no natural stopping point for your desires.

pairs.stoic_text:
Remember that you must behave as at a banquet. Is anything brought round
to you? Put out your hand and take a moderate share. Does it pass by you?
Do not stop it. Is it not yet come? Do not yearn in desire toward it, but
wait till it reaches you. So with regard to children, wife, office,
riches; and you will some time or other be worthy to feast with the gods.
And if you do not so much as take the things which are set before you,
but are able even to forego them, then you will not only be worthy to
feast with the gods, but to rule with them also. For, by thus doing,
Diogenes and Heraclitus, and others like them, deservedly became divine,
and were so recognized.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's the same text in plain language:

You should act like you're at a dinner party. When something is offered to you, take a reasonable amount. If it's not offered to you, don't try to stop it or grab it. If it hasn't arrived yet, don't desperately want it - just wait for your turn. Apply this same approach to your children, spouse, job, and money. If you do this, you will eventually become worthy of great things.

If you can go even further and choose not to take things that are available to you, then you will be worthy of even greater things. Philosophers like Diogenes and Heraclitus became highly respected by following this principle of self-control.

pairs.stoic_text:
As in a voyage, when the ship is at anchor, if you go on shore to get
water, you may amuse yourself with picking up a shellfish or a truffle in
your way, but your thoughts ought to be bent toward the ship, and
perpetually attentive, lest the captain should call, and then you must
leave all these things, that you may not have to be carried on board the
vessel, bound like a sheep; thus likewise in life, if, instead of a
truffle or shellfish, such a thing as a wife or a child be granted you,
there is no objection; but if the captain calls, run to the ship, leave
all these things, and never look behind. But if you are old, never go far
from the ship, lest you should be missing when called for.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's the same text in plain language:

Life is like being a passenger on a ship. When the ship stops and you go ashore to get supplies, you can enjoy collecting small things like shells or mushrooms along the way. But you must always keep your attention on the ship and listen for the captain's call to return. When the captain calls, you have to drop everything and hurry back, or else you'll be dragged aboard against your will.

The same principle applies to life. It's fine to enjoy good things like having a spouse or children, just as you might enjoy finding shells on the beach. However, when death calls (like the captain calling), you must be ready to let go of everything without resistance or regret.

If you are elderly, don't get too attached to worldly things or stray too far from being prepared, because you might be called at any time.

pairs.stoic_text:
In company, avoid a frequent and excessive mention of your own actions
and dangers. For however agreeable it may be to yourself to allude to the
risks you have run, it is not equally agreeable to others to hear your
adventures. Avoid likewise an endeavor to excite laughter, for this may
readily slide you into vulgarity, and, besides, may be apt to lower you
in the esteem of your acquaintance. Approaches to indecent discourse are
likewise dangerous. Therefore, when anything of this sort happens, use
the first fit opportunity to rebuke him who makes advances that way, or,
at least, by silence and blushing and a serious look show yourself to be
displeased by such talk.
pairs.neutral_text:
When you're with other people, don't talk too much about things you've done or dangerous situations you've been in. You might enjoy telling these stories, but others don't necessarily want to hear about your experiences all the time. 

Also, don't try too hard to make people laugh. This can lead you to say crude things, and it might make people think less of you. 

Be careful when conversations turn toward inappropriate topics. If someone starts talking about indecent subjects, either speak up against it when you get the chance, or at minimum show through your silence, embarrassment, and serious expression that you disapprove of that kind of talk.

pairs.stoic_text:
Upon every accident, remember to turn toward yourself and inquire what
faculty you have for its use. If you encounter a handsome person, you
will find continence the faculty needed; if pain, then fortitude; if
reviling, then patience. And when thus habituated, the phenomena of
existence will not overwhelm you.
pairs.neutral_text: When something happens to you, look at yourself and figure out what skill you need to handle it. If you meet an attractive person, you'll need self-control. If you experience pain, you'll need courage. If someone insults you, you'll need patience. If you practice this regularly, life's events won't be too much for you to handle.

pairs.stoic_text:
Thus we do not have any original writings of Epictetus. Like G. H. Mead
in recent times, he was completely dedicated to the human and
intellectual problems of his students. He left it for them to preserve
what they considered to be the lasting message of the teacher. In
contrast to Seneca and Marcus Aurelius, Epictetus had no subjective
approach to the Stoic doctrines. Moral philosophy was the center of his
teaching, and epistemology was only instrumental. It is even permissible
to say that he took physics or cosmology too lightly. If this is granted,
we must admit that he is completely absorbed by the fundamentals of Stoic
thought as presented in the _Enchiridion_. Epictetus’ personality is
totally integrated in the act of reasoning which establishes conformity
with nature.
pairs.neutral_text: We do not have any writings that Epictetus wrote himself. Like G. H. Mead in modern times, he focused entirely on helping his students with personal and intellectual issues. He let his students decide what parts of his teaching were important enough to write down and save. Unlike Seneca and Marcus Aurelius, Epictetus did not apply Stoic ideas to his own personal experiences. He taught mainly about ethics and morality, and only used logic and reasoning as tools to support this teaching. He may have paid too little attention to physics and theories about the universe. Given this focus, Epictetus concentrated completely on the basic ideas of Stoicism that appear in the *Enchiridion*. His personality and identity were entirely shaped by the logical thinking that aimed to live in harmony with nature.

pairs.stoic_text:
The will of nature may be learned from things upon which we are all
agreed. As when our neighbor’s boy has broken a cup, or the like, we are
ready at once to say, “These are casualties that will happen”; be
assured, then, that when your own cup is likewise broken, you ought to be
affected just as when another’s cup was broken. Now apply this to greater
things. Is the child or wife of another dead? There is no one who would
not say, “This is an accident of mortality.” But if anyone’s own child
happens to die, it is immediately, “Alas! how wretched am I!” It should
be always remembered how we are affected on hearing the same thing
concerning others.
pairs.neutral_text:
We can understand how things naturally work by looking at situations where everyone agrees. When our neighbor's child breaks a cup, we immediately say "accidents happen." You should have the same reaction when your own cup breaks.

This same principle applies to more serious situations. When someone else's child or spouse dies, everyone says "death is a natural part of life." But when our own child dies, we say "how terrible this is for me!" We should remember to react to our own losses the same way we react when hearing about other people's losses.

pairs.stoic_text:
The little book by Epictetus called _Enchiridion_ or “manual” has played
a disproportionately large role in the rise of modern attitudes and
modern philosophy. As soon as it had been translated into the vernacular
languages, it became a bestseller among independent intellectuals, among
anti-Christian thinkers, and among philosophers of a subjective cast.
Montaigne had a copy of the _Enchiridion_ among his books. Pascal
violently rejected the megalomaniac pride of the Stoic philosopher.
Frederick the Great carried the book with him on all campaigns. It was a
source of inspiration and encouragement to Anthony, Earl of Shaftesbury,
in the serious illness which ended only in his death; many pages of his
diaries contain passages copied from the _Enchiridion_. It has been
studied and widely quoted by Scottish philosophers like Francis
Hutcheson, Adam Smith, and Adam Ferguson who valued Stoic moral
philosophy for its reconciliation of social dependency and personal
independence.
pairs.neutral_text: The small book by Epictetus called _Enchiridion_ or "manual" has had a much larger influence on modern thinking and philosophy than its size would suggest. After it was translated into common languages, it became very popular with independent thinkers, people who opposed Christianity, and philosophers who focused on individual experience. Montaigne owned a copy of the _Enchiridion_. Pascal strongly criticized what he saw as the excessive pride of Stoic philosophy. Frederick the Great brought the book with him during all his military campaigns. The book provided inspiration and comfort to Anthony, Earl of Shaftesbury, during the serious illness that eventually killed him; he copied many passages from the _Enchiridion_ into his personal diaries. Scottish philosophers like Francis Hutcheson, Adam Smith, and Adam Ferguson studied and frequently quoted the book because they appreciated how Stoic moral philosophy balanced the need to depend on others with maintaining personal freedom.

pairs.stoic_text:
The first and most necessary topic in philosophy is the practical
application of principles, as, _We ought not to lie_; the second is that
of demonstrations as, _Why it is that we ought not to lie_; the third,
that which gives strength and logical connection to the other two, as,
_Why this is a demonstration_. For what is demonstration? What is a
consequence? What a contradiction? What truth? What falsehood? The third
point is then necessary on account of the second; and the second on
account of the first. But the most necessary, and that whereon we ought
to rest, is the first. But we do just the contrary. For we spend all our
time on the third point and employ all our diligence about that, and
entirely neglect the first. Therefore, at the same time that we lie, we
are very ready to show how it is demonstrated that lying is wrong.
pairs.neutral_text:
Philosophy has three main areas of study. The first area deals with applying principles in practice, such as "We should not lie." The second area focuses on proving why these principles are correct, such as "Why we should not lie." The third area examines the logical foundations that support the other two areas, such as "Why this proof is valid."

This third area asks questions like: What makes a proof valid? What is a logical consequence? What is a contradiction? What is truth? What is falsehood? The third area exists to support the second area, and the second area exists to support the first area. The first area should be the most important and where we focus our attention.

However, we do the opposite. We spend most of our time on the third area and put all our effort into studying logical foundations, while we completely ignore the first area of practical application. As a result, we can explain why lying is wrong while we are actually lying ourselves.

pairs.stoic_text:
Begin therefore with little things. Is a little oil spilled or a little
wine stolen? Say to yourself, “This is the price paid for peace and
tranquillity; and nothing is to be had for nothing.” And when you call
your servant, consider that it is possible he may not come at your call;
or, if he does, that he may not do what you wish. But it is not at all
desirable for him, and very undesirable for you, that it should be in his
power to cause you any disturbance.
pairs.neutral_text: Start with small problems. If some oil gets spilled or someone steals a little wine, tell yourself that this is what you pay for staying calm and peaceful - everything has a cost. When you ask your servant to do something, remember that he might not respond, or if he does respond, he might not do what you want. However, it's not good for him to have the ability to upset you, and it's definitely bad for you if he can disturb your peace of mind.

pairs.stoic_text:
If you would improve, lay aside such reasonings as these: “If I neglect
my affairs, I shall not have a maintenance; if I do not punish my
servant, he will be good for nothing.” For it were better to die of
hunger, exempt from grief and fear, than to live in affluence with
perturbation; and it is better that your servant should be bad than you
unhappy.
pairs.neutral_text:
If you want to get better at living well, stop thinking this way: "If I don't take care of my business, I won't have money to live on; if I don't discipline my employee, they won't work properly." 

It's better to starve to death while feeling calm and unafraid than to be wealthy but constantly worried and upset. It's also better to have a poorly performing employee than to make yourself miserable trying to control them.

pairs.stoic_text:
When you have learned to nourish your body frugally, do not pique
yourself upon it; nor, if you drink water, be saying upon every occasion,
“I drink water.” But first consider how much more frugal are the poor
than we, and how much more patient of hardship. If at any time you would
inure yourself by exercise to labor and privation, for your own sake and
not for the public, do not attempt great feats; but when you are
violently thirsty, just rinse your mouth with water, and tell nobody.
pairs.neutral_text:
When you learn to eat simply and spend less money on food, don't be proud of it or brag about it. If you choose to drink water instead of other beverages, don't constantly tell people "I drink water." Remember that poor people live much more simply than we do and handle difficult conditions much better than we do. 

If you want to train yourself to handle hard work and going without things, do it for your own benefit, not to impress others. Don't try to do extreme things. When you're very thirsty, just rinse your mouth with water and don't tell anyone about it.

pairs.stoic_text:
If you would improve, be content to be thought foolish and dull with
regard to externals. Do not desire to be thought to know anything; and
though you should appear to others to be somebody, distrust yourself. For
be assured, it is not easy at once to keep your will in harmony with
nature and to secure externals; but while you are absorbed in the one,
you must of necessity neglect the other.
pairs.neutral_text:
If you want to get better at philosophy, accept that other people might think you're ignorant about worldly matters. Don't try to impress others with your knowledge. Even if people think highly of you, question your own abilities. 

It's difficult to focus on living according to philosophical principles while also pursuing external success and recognition. When you concentrate on one area, you will inevitably have less time and energy for the other.

pairs.stoic_text:
When anyone shows himself vain on being able to understand and interpret
the works of Chrysippus,[7] say to yourself: “Unless Chrysippus had
written obscurely, this person would have had nothing to be vain of. But
what do I desire? To understand nature, and follow her. I ask, then, who
interprets her; and hearing that Chrysippus does, I have recourse to him.
I do not understand his writings. I seek, therefore, one to interpret
_them_.” So far there is nothing to value myself upon. And when I find an
interpreter, what remains is to make use of his instructions. This alone
is the valuable thing. But if I admire merely the interpretation, what do
I become more than a grammarian, instead of a philosopher, except,
indeed, that instead of Homer I interpret Chrysippus? When anyone,
therefore, desires me to read Chrysippus to him, I rather blush when I
cannot exhibit actions that are harmonious and consonant with his
discourse.
pairs.neutral_text: When someone brags about being able to understand and explain Chrysippus's writings, think this: "If Chrysippus had written clearly, this person would have nothing to brag about. But what do I want? I want to understand nature and live according to it. I ask who can explain nature to me, and I'm told Chrysippus can, so I go to his works. I don't understand what he wrote, so I look for someone to explain it to me." There's nothing impressive about this so far. When I find someone who can explain it, the only thing left is to actually follow the teachings. That's the only thing that matters. If I just admire the explanations themselves, I'm no better than a language scholar instead of a philosopher—except I'm studying Chrysippus instead of Homer. So when someone asks me to read Chrysippus with them, I feel embarrassed when my actions don't match what his teachings say I should do.

pairs.stoic_text:
When a raven happens to croak unluckily, be not overcome by appearances,
but discriminate and say, “Nothing is portended to _me_, either to my
paltry body, or property, or reputation, or children, or wife. But to
_me_ all portents are lucky if I will. For whatsoever happens, it belongs
to me to derive advantage therefrom.”
pairs.neutral_text: When you hear a raven make noise at what seems like a bad time, don't let the situation control your emotions. Instead, think clearly and tell yourself: "This doesn't predict anything bad for me, my body, my possessions, my reputation, my children, or my spouse. For me, all signs can be positive if I choose to see them that way. Whatever happens, I can find a way to benefit from it."

pairs.stoic_text:
Does anyone bathe hastily? Do not say that he does it ill, but hastily.
Does anyone drink much wine? Do not say that he does ill, but that he
drinks a great deal. For unless you perfectly understand his motives, how
should you know if he acts ill? Thus you will not risk yielding to any
appearances but such as you fully comprehend.
pairs.neutral_text: When someone bathes quickly, don't say they're bathing poorly - just say they're bathing quickly. When someone drinks a lot of wine, don't say they're doing something wrong - just say they drink a lot. You can't know if someone is acting badly unless you completely understand why they're doing it. This way, you'll avoid making judgments based on incomplete information.

pairs.stoic_text:
Aiming, therefore, at such great things, remember that you must not allow
yourself any inclination, however slight, toward the attainment of the
others; but that you must entirely quit some of them, and for the present
postpone the rest. But if you would have these, and possess power and
wealth likewise, you may miss the latter in seeking the former; and you
will certainly fail of that by which alone happiness and freedom are
procured.
pairs.neutral_text: When you're trying to achieve important goals, don't let yourself be distracted by wanting other things, even a little bit. You need to completely give up some desires and put others on hold for now. If you try to pursue your main goals while also seeking power and wealth, you might fail to get the power and wealth. More importantly, you'll definitely fail to achieve the things that actually bring happiness and freedom.

pairs.stoic_text:
Be mostly silent, or speak merely what is needful, and in few words. We
may, however, enter sparingly into discourse sometimes, when occasion
calls for it; but let it not run on any of the common subjects, as
gladiators, or horse races, or athletic champions, or food, or drink—the
vulgar topics of conversation—and especially not on men, so as either to
blame, or praise, or make comparisons. If you are able, then, by your own
conversation, bring over that of your company to proper subjects; but if
you happen to find yourself among strangers, be silent.
pairs.neutral_text: Stay quiet most of the time, or only say what's necessary using few words. You can sometimes have conversations when the situation requires it, but don't talk about common topics like gladiators, horse races, athletes, food, or drinks—these are ordinary conversation subjects. Especially avoid talking about other people in ways that criticize them, praise them, or compare them to others. If you can, try to steer your group's conversation toward better topics through your own contributions. However, if you're with people you don't know, stay quiet.

pairs.stoic_text:
It is not necessary for you to appear often at public spectacles; but if
ever there is a proper occasion for you to be there, do not appear more
solicitous for any other than for yourself—that is, wish things to be
only just as they are, and only the best man to win; for thus nothing
will go against you. But abstain entirely from acclamations and derision
and violent emotions. And when you come away, do not discourse a great
deal on what has passed and what contributes nothing to your own
amendment. For it would appear by such discourse that you were dazzled by
the show.
pairs.neutral_text: You don't need to attend public events very often. When you do go to appropriate events, don't favor any particular participant over others. Just accept whatever happens and hope the most deserving person wins. This way you won't be disappointed by the outcome. Don't cheer loudly, mock anyone, or get emotionally worked up. After the event, don't spend a lot of time talking about what happened, since this kind of discussion doesn't help you improve yourself. Talking too much about the event shows that you were overly impressed by it.

pairs.stoic_text:
As the proposition, “either it is day or it is night,” has much force in
a disjunctive argument, but none at all in a conjunctive one, so, at a
feast, to choose the largest share is very suitable to the bodily
appetite, but utterly inconsistent with the social spirit of the
entertainment. Remember, then, when you eat with another, not only the
value to the body of those things which are set before you, but also the
value of proper courtesy toward your host.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's the same text in plain language:

Just like the statement "either it is day or it is night" works well when you need to choose between options but doesn't work when you're trying to combine things, different behaviors are appropriate in different situations. When you're eating alone, it makes sense to take the biggest portion to satisfy your hunger. But when you're at a dinner party, taking the largest share goes against the social purpose of sharing a meal together.

So when you eat with other people, don't just think about how much food will satisfy your body. Also consider how to be polite and respectful to the person who invited you.

pairs.stoic_text:
When you are going before anyone in power, fancy to yourself that you may
not find him at home, that you may be shut out, that the doors may not be
opened to you, that he may not notice you. If, with all this, it be your
duty to go, bear what happens and never say to yourself, “It was not
worth so much”; for this is vulgar, and like a man bewildered by
externals.
pairs.neutral_text:
When you need to meet with someone who has authority or power, prepare yourself for possible problems. They might not be available, you might not be allowed in, the doors could be closed, or they might ignore you. 

If you still have a responsibility to go despite these possibilities, accept whatever happens. Don't tell yourself afterward "it wasn't worth the trouble." This kind of complaining is crude and shows you're too focused on things outside your control.

pairs.stoic_text:
Now the things within our power are by nature free, unrestricted,
unhindered; but those beyond our power are weak, dependent, restricted,
alien. Remember, then, that if you attribute freedom to things by nature
dependent and take what belongs to others for your own, you will be
hindered, you will lament, you will be disturbed, you will find fault
both with gods and men. But if you take for your own only that which is
your own and view what belongs to others just as it really is, then no
one will ever compel you, no one will restrict you; you will find fault
with no one, you will accuse no one, you will do nothing against your
will; no one will hurt you, you will not have an enemy, nor will you
suffer any harm.
pairs.neutral_text:
Some things are under your control, and some things are not. The things you can control are naturally free and unlimited. The things you cannot control are weak, dependent, and limited.

If you mistakenly think you can control things that are actually beyond your control, or if you try to claim things that belong to other people, you will face obstacles, feel sad, become upset, and blame both gods and other people.

However, if you only focus on controlling what is actually yours to control, and you accept that other things belong to others or are outside anyone's control, then no one can force you to do anything or limit you. You won't blame anyone or complain about anyone. You'll only do things you choose to do. No one will be able to hurt you, you won't have enemies, and you won't experience harm.

pairs.stoic_text:
When you set about any action, remind yourself of what nature the action
is. If you are going to bathe, represent to yourself the incidents usual
in the bath—some persons pouring out, others pushing in, others scolding,
others pilfering. And thus you will more safely go about this action if
you say to yourself, “I will now go to bathe and keep my own will in
harmony with nature.” And so with regard to every other action. For thus,
if any impediment arises in bathing, you will be able to say, “It was not
only to bathe that I desired, but to keep my will in harmony with nature;
and I shall not keep it thus if I am out of humor at things that happen.”
pairs.neutral_text: Before you do anything, think about what that activity normally involves. If you're going to take a bath, remember what usually happens at the bathhouse - some people are leaving, others are pushing to get in, some are arguing, and others are stealing. You'll handle the situation better if you tell yourself, "I'm going to bathe and stay calm about whatever happens." Do this same thing before any activity. This way, if something goes wrong while you're bathing, you can remind yourself, "I didn't just come here to bathe - I came here to practice staying calm when things don't go as planned. If I get angry about what's happening, I'm failing at that goal."
